text:
MULTIDIMENSIONAL ATTRIBUTE ANALYSIS AND 
PATTERN RECOGNITION FOR SEISMIC INTERPRETATION

J. H. JUSTICE, I D. J. HAWKINS 2 and G. WONG 1 
J Department of Geology and Geophysics, The University of Calgary, Calgary, Alberta, Canada T2N IN4, 
and 2Dipix Systems Limited, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada K2E 7J5
(Received 7 December 1984; received for publication 5 March 1985)

Al~traet--The interpretation of exploration seismic data to infer the probable locations of commercial 
quantities of hydrocarbons has deep roots in pattern analysis. In this paper we suggest a broad-based 
program or framework for treating the interpretation of seismic data as a problem or a collection of many 
problems in pattern recognition. 
The basis for this approach is the identification of a large number of objective or quantitative attributes 
which may be combined in a variety of ways via pattern analysis to infer the information necessary to 
accurately interpret exploration seismic data, and to locate potentially commercial hydrocarbon reservoirs.

Seismic 
Cluster analysis 
Analytic signal 
Bright spots 
Interactive pattern analysis
!. INTRODUCTION

The interpretation of seismic data to infer the probable 
locations of commercial accumulations of hydrocar- 
bons has deep roots in pattern analysis. Over a period 
of many years, the experience of many field cases has 
been accumulated; comparisons of data with the 
results of drilling have been made; geological and 
geophysical knowledge have begun to be integrated 
and, slowly, unified approaches to seismic interpret- 
ation based on sound geological and geophysical 
principles have begun to emerge, almost always related 
in various ways to the concepts of pattern recognition 
and analysis. 
The earliest discoveries using geophysical methods 
were based on the identification of probable structural 
traps for hydrocarbons using observed traveltimes 
derived from reflections of acoustic energy from inter- 
faces in the Earth separating different lithologic units. 
A variety of trapping mechanisms were identified and 
the structural configurations of these traps were 
sought as a simple form ofpattern recognition on data 
which had been processed and displayed in such a way 
as to approximate a cross section of the near surface 
material in the Earth (usually not exceeding depths of 
about 10 kin). 
It wasn't very long before the concept of a different 
type of trap began to assume importance, this being 
known as the stratigraphic trap. A stratigraphic trap 
may be constrasted to a structural trap by referring to 
one of the first definitions given for these two concepts 
by Marr: tt~ 
"A structural trap is one where sedimentary rocks have 
been folded and possibly faulted to produce a domal or 
anticlinal shaped closure, irrespective of size, that is 
capable of trapping hydrocarbons in porous blanket

, 
1985 Pattern Recognition Sociel)

strata which are arched over the top of the fold or 
uplift. 
Stratigraphic traps are all porous rock masses in the 
subsurface which can !rap hydrocarbons and which 
are not structural traps. This includes [paraphrase]: 
1. blanket porous strata which are truncated or 
pinched out ... 
2. porous strata which terminate by lateral transition 
into nonporous strata 
3. porous strata interrupted by barriers of all kinds, 
such as permeability, pressure, secondary min- 
eralization, etc. 
4. strand lines of either elastics or carbonates. 
5. reefs, buried topography, lenses, bars, etc." 
While there may be disagreement on the actual 
forms of these definitions or even their precise mean- 
ing, there is a significant implication in the distinction 
made here. That is, that while a stratigraphic trap may 
well have a structural expression (reefs, lenses, bars, 
etc.), it becomes of interest only when the probable 
depositional environment and therefore the actual 
nature of the lithoiogic unit is inferred in some way. 
That is, the identification of a reef suggests the 
possibility of porous hydrocarbon reservoirs within 
what may be a larger carbonate/evaporite complex. 
The identification of bars or channel sands suggest 
lithologies conducive to hydrocarbon reservoirs, i.e. 
porosities and permeabilities suitable for the accumu- 
lation of hydrocarbons, provided that some trapping 
agent such as an impervious seal to the reservoir and a 
source of hydrocarbons to charge the reservoir are 
both present. 
The implication is, then, that we must go beyond 
structure and infer probable lithologies and probable 
presence of hydrocarbons. The first step in this direc- 
tion was suggested above in the form of a "facies"
CDP
Gathers

Stack 
CDP Section 
IAgrate
Fig. 1. Seismic processing and imaging.

analysis to determine the probable environment of 
deposition leading to an identification of the probable 
lithologies and their characteristics. 
Today, we may apply many sophisticated proce- 
dures to the interpretation of seismic data, using a 
relatively large number of attributes, in an attempt to 
infer as much information as possible about the actual 
structure and composition of the stratigraphic section 
in the region of interest. 
The trend, therefore, is toward identification of 
lithoiogic parameters as a function of depth and lateral 
position within the Earth and these may include the 
inference of elastic parameters, and their associated 
physical expressions including velocities, as well as 
densities, porosity and permeability, probable grain 
size and distribution (elastics), degree of saturation, 
and the nature of the saturating fluids (oil, gas, brine, 
for example) and their pressures, and the probable 
mineralogical composition and integrity of the rock. 
The seismic method is by far the most widely used 
method in the quest for hydrocarbon traps but it is 
supplemented by many additional types of measure- 
ments, particularly those which may be made in the 
borehole once a well is drilled. We may try, therefore to 
relate borehole measurements to seismic expressions 
in order to extrapolate properties of producing 
horizons, for example, away from the borehole. This, in 
turn, constitutes an interesting problem in pattern 
analysis and recognition. 
Having thus stated that our goal is the extraction of 
as much information as possible from seismic data, let 
us go on to begin to quantify and to formulate our 
problem as one ultimately involving many aspects of 
pattern analysis and recognition. 
Our program for approaching this problem and for 
integrating the various data which may be provided 
for analysis is to keep the human element in the pattern 
recognition/interpretation process to the greatest pos- 
sible degree. This is done through the use of an
NMO

interactive computer/image analysis system which can 
present many types of data and results ofdata analysis, 
as well as operational tools including pattern recog- 
nition algorithms, to the interpreter for his use. We do 
not feel that a completely automated system is yet 
possible which can replace the human element in this 
pro~ss.

II. BRIEF OVERVIEW OF SEISMIC DATA 
AND DISPLAY

Seismic data results from recording the energy 
which returns to the surface of the Earth from a high 
energy source of acoustic waves (a buried dynamite 
explosion for example) propagating downward into 
the Earth and reflecting back to the surface whenever a 
change in acoustic impedance (velocity times density) 
occurs. Usually velocity or density variations occur at 
the boundaries between layers which are more-or-less 
lithologically homogeneous and so the reflecting bound- 
aries tend to conform with the lithologic boundaries of 
interest within the Earth. Even more precisely, they 
tend to conform to common (chronological) time 
events, i.e. chronostratigraphic boundaries within the 
Earth. 
Today, the most common format for gathenng and 
displaying seismic data is the CDP (common depth 
point) or, more properly CMP (common mid point) 
format. In this method, a single reflecting point on an 
(assumed) horizontal reflector is imaged from several 
different offsets between sources and receivers (Fig. 1). 
In the case of many overlying layers, ray tracing is 
usually used to estimate the actual travel paths 
followed, and, from observed two-way travel times, 
information concerning 'average' velocities to the 
reflector can be inferred. From these velocities some 
inference of interval velocities within the layers can 
also be made. 
The travel-time data for a single (assumed) reflecting

point is then corrected for the corresponding offset of 
the source and receiver and the resulting corrected 
trace for this source-receiver pair represents data 
which would have been obtained at a coincident 
source-receiver pair directly above the reflecting point 
('normal move-out' or NMO correction). 
Since there were many such source-receiver pairs 
(each with different offset) used in the data acquisition 
stage, we now have many seismic traces representing 
the signal which would have been obtained by the 
same coincident source-receiver pair at the surface 
above the (assumed) reflecting point. 
These traces are now 'stacked' (summed) in order to 
improve signal-to-noise ratio. If we have done our 
corrections well, the desired (primary) reflections from 
the interface will add in phase and other events, 
coherent or incoherent will tend to sum out of phase 
and so be eliminated in this 'stacking' process. 
At this point we may try to remove the 'blurring' 
effect of the actual source wavelet by attempting to 
"deconvolve' it from the trace to produce a perfect 
impulse response. We are limited in these efforts by 
imperfect knowledge of this wavelet and by the fact 
that seismic data is severely band-limited,'having lost 
both low and high frequencies. 
if we now place the processed trace for each 
reflecting point side-by-side at the surface position of 
this common mid point (the coincident source- 
receiver Iocation), an image will appear from the 
alignment of reflection events from contiguous re- 
flectors forming a kind of image of the subsurface with 
two-way time in place of the depth variable. 
The image will, in general, be distorted due to the 
original assumption of a horizontal reflector, which is 
not usually met in practice. This assumption led us to 
incorrectly place the reflecting point beneath the 
common mid point (CMP) location. 
We may correct the data for this error by performing 
an additional (image) processing step which 'migrates' 
the reflection (approximately) to its correct location 
within the section. 
The resulting display showing the approximate 
configuration of reflecting horizons within the Earth as 
well as information (including velocities) obtained 
from the original data set shall become the focal point 
of our attention in an attempt to identify the kind of 
information we seek (Section I). 
The interested reader is referred to Robinson and 
Treitel, TM Sheriff ~3~ and Wood and Treitel ~4~ for further 
discussion of the topics in this section.

IlL ATTRIBUTES DERIVABLE FROM SEISMIC DATA 
AND THEIR USE IN PATTERN RECOGNITION

in our work in pattern recognition for seismic 
interpretation we have established a rather broad 
program which includes the use of many visual or 
mathematically derivable attributes each of which 
contributes in some way to constructing an image of 
the subsurface which is as complete as possible with
Table I. Seismic attributes

I. Amplitude 
2. Computed attenuation/frequency parameters 
3. Velocity

respect to the lithologic parameters of interest which 
have been mentioned earlier. 
We shall begin with a discussion of the most 
commonly used attributes for this analysis and shall 
then discuss these separately or in groups indicating 
how we have integrated them into our overall program 
of pattern recognition and interpretation. 
As mentioned earlier, we have tried to make max- 
imum use of human pattern recognition capabilities by 
utilizing an interactive computer/imaging system 
rather than attempting to design a completely auto- 
mated system which we feel could only poorly approxi- 
mate human interaction at this time. We do however, 
present access to a variety of automated pattern 
recognition procedures for the interpreter to aid in 
evaluation and decision making based on his knowl- 
edge of the prospect and the other data which is at his 
disposal. 
Recalling that our goal is nothing short of a 
complete inference and understanding of all the litho- 
logic characteristics of interest (and understanding 
that this goal is by no means achievable today) we have 
identified the set of attributes listed in Table I to be 
used in pattern recognition/interpretation as applied 
to seismic data. 
Of course the list in Table 1 is not mutually 
exclusive, there is some overlap between the various 
components on this list and other attributes may be 
added which are not explicitly listed here. Given a 
large multidimensional set of attributes such as those 
listed, we can then use this set with a variety of pattern 
analysis/recognition 
algorithms 
including, 
for 
example, classification and cluster analysis; image 
analysis and recognition algorithms such as matched 
filters; scale and translation invariant pattern recog- 
nition algorithms, etc. 
Our approach is to present the attributes and 
procedures to the interpreter via an imaging system 
which allows a wide variety of displays, including split 
screen capability, design and use of color look-up 
tables, superposition of images, image processing 
algorithms (edge detectors, filters, etc.) and pattern 
analysis graphical displays (cluster diagrams, etc.). 
We may now summarize, in tabular form, some of 
the types of information which can be derived from the

IV. SEISMIC FACIES ANALYSIS AND 
STRUCTURAL/b~'rRATIGRAPH IC PA'I'rERNS

We cannot hope to present here a comprehensive 
discussion of seismic facies analysis since many vol- 
umes could be and have been written on this subject. 
However, we do want to discuss this in relation to our
Fig. 2. A seismic section.

program of interactive interpretation assisted by pat- 
tern recognition as an important piece of that puzzle, 
Geometric seismic facies analysis relates to the most 
classical aspects of pattern recognition in that we seek 
to identify and classify (visual) patterns in the data as a 
guide to inferring the original depositional environ- 
ment and, thereby, draw some conclusions concerning 
probable rock types and characteristics as an aid in 
interpreting the other types of data we shall derive. 
Environments of deposition in sedimentary basins 
may be roughly divided into three main categories. ~s)

f 
Fluviatile 
1. Continental 
Lacustrine 
Eolian

2. Transitional 
[" Lobate (deltas) 
(shorelines) 
~ linear 
f

reer 
shelf 
3. Marine 
turbidite
pelagic

After Selley: (5) 
"A sedimentary facies is a coherent unit of sedimen- 
tary rock which may be distinguished from other units 
by such attributes as geometry, lithology, sedimentary 
structures and fossils." 
"Seismic facies analysis is the description and inter- 
pretation of seismic reflection parameters including

geometry, continuity, amplitude, frequency and inter- 
val velocity. "~6) 
A sedimentary facies will generally be identified with 
one of the three main sedimentary environments listed 
above and will be classified in seismic data primarily 
on the basis of seismic patterns (geometry) within the 
facies and their relation to the surrounding strata as 
revealed in the seismic section. Identification of a facies 
may include consideration of probable sinking or 
uplift of the basement structure during deposition; and 
rise, fall, or stillstand of sea level during this period. In 
addition to determining the depositional environment 
we also attempt to infer the probable source of the 
sediments and their "energy' which may provide a clue 
to grain size and distribution and which may in turn 
indicate probable zones where porosity may occur and 
probable zones where source rocks or seals may have 
formed. Facies may often be bounded in a natural way 
by unconformities. 
Various attempts have been made to classify a basic 
set of patterns (geometry) which tend to reveal the 
information referred to above. In particular, a basic set 
of seismic reflection patterns is identified in Sangree 
and Widmier. 
Atlases of sedimentary structures have 
been compiled and may be found in Selley ~5) for 
example. These may be combined in various ways to 
reveal the depositional history of the unit. ~6" 8) 
Sangree and Widmier ~) and Sheriff 9) show the 
relations of these patterns to common depositional

L 
550 
P 
l 
ZOOM 
. 
DIPIX
Fig. 3. Zero crossing display.

environments and give the relationship between the 
seismic attribute and its geological interpretation. In 
carrying out an interpretation based on reflection 
geometry, as we have described here, it is important to 
present the interpreter with several capabilities which 
enhance his ability to properly interpret the selected 
facies. 
First it is important to have a sharp, clean display of 
the geometric (structural) information revealed in the 
seismic section. Figure 2 shows a portion of a seismic 
section, as it might appear on our image analysis 
system, representing an image of the subsurface which 
has been constructed as explained previously. One 
alternative form of display, for example, would be to 
image zero crossings as shown in Fig. 3. The data 
should not be contaminated heavily by noise in order 
to use this procedure. A second alternative which turns 
out to be quite useful in this respect is a phase display. 
This type of display will be discussed later. We may 
then apply various procedures such as smoothing and 
edge detectors to the data in order to enhance 
continuity of reflections or to highlight discontinuities 
which may result from faulting or other terminations 
of the reflector. 
Another useful procedure is to be able to 'flatten' (or 
otherwise distort) a given reflecting horizon which has 
been identified such as an erosional surface (un-

conformity). By distorting a horizon back to its 
probable shape at the time of its occurrence, we can 
infer the actual configuration at that time of the 
underlying facies. A river channel which is sand-filled 
and subsequently buried by clays may take the form 
(due to differential compaction) shown in Fig. 4a. 
Flattening on the upper horizon clearly reveals the 
original structure of the river channel as shown in Fig. 
4b. 
Flattening on the lower horizon may indicate a 
mound such as a reef occurrance as shown in Fig. 4c. 
We have to look further to identify the correct choice 
between these two possibilities. In the actual example 
illustrated the reef would b ruled out because it would 
have to have continued growing after the layer above it 
(which does not thin across the mound) had been 
deposited--an unlikely scenario. 
Finally, we may apply certain pattern recognition 
algorithms such as scale and translation invariant 
pattern recognition, horizon tracking, and image 
processing to identify locations in the data where 
pinchouts, faulting, etc. may have occurred. 
We have given some indication of how we approach 
facie analysis using reflection geometry and some of 
the imaging/recognition tools which have been de- 
scribed in conjunction with an interactive imaging 
system. The final identification of the pattern (the

j
~
Fig. 4. Buried channel.

decision process) has been left to the interpreter. 
The other attributes which we shall analyze all 
contribute to facies analysis in various ways but we 
shall consider them separately and in relation to 
additional examples. Because of the enormity of this 
subject, we shall discuss the use of many of these 
attributes only by way of example. 
Structural and stratigraphic expressions of several 
types of traps are shown in Fig. 5. "~ Figure 5A shows 
an anticline trap which is the type of trap associated 
with the very first oil discovery and for some time was 
thought to be the only trapping mechanism for 
petroleum hydrocarbons. The existence of free gas in 
this type of trap depends on the pressures present in the 
reservoir. At high pressures, the gas will go into 
solution in the oil and at lower pressures will appear as 
shown. This type of trap is an example of structural 
trap. In Fig. 5B is shown a salt dome which is formed 
by the plastic flow of buried salts which may be the 
result of evaporation of an ancient sea bed. As the salt 
is buried and subjected to increasing pressure, it is 
capable of plastic flow and can force its way up 
through the sedimentary overburden, pulling the beds 
up alongside its flanks. This upward dip, terminating 
against the impermeable salt, produces a potential 
trapping mechanism and, indeed, this type of trap is 
very common in the Gulf Coast region of the United 
States. Many early traps which were found in this 
region were of this type.

In Fig. 5C, a stratigraphic trap is shown consisting 
of a dipping bed in which a change of porosity occurs 
due to diagenesis of the layer to the left creating pore 
space. Stratigraphic traps can be extremely subtle and 
difficult to detect using seismic methods but they are 
becoming more and more important as the more easily 
detected structural traps which have not been found 
became fewer in number. In Fig. 5D, a reef trap is 
shown, which is important in many pools found in 
North America, including Texas and New Mexico, 
Michigan, and Western Canada, for example. These 
reefs frequently still contain porous material and often 
are associated with source rocks, such as bituminous 
shales, surrounding them. 
In Fig. 5E another common type of trap is shown, 
known as the fault trap, which is produced as a result of 
faulting in the Earth, which may bring an impermeable 
sediment into contact with a porous and permeable 
one as shown in the illustration. The oil migrates 
through the permeable layer until it encounters the 
impermeable material into which it cannot flow, and 
so a trap is formed. Finally, in Fig. 5F, we see an 
example of a hydrologic trap in which water pressure 
due to surface waters entering folded strata at both 
ends holds the oil in place due to the pressure of the 
formation waters. An example of this type of trap 
would be the San Juan Basin in New Mexico.

V. ATTRIBUTES DERIVABLE FROM THE ANALYTIC 
SIGNAL

If we are given a seismic trace s, we can calculate 
another trace, q, the Hilbert transform of s, so that the 
complex signal
w(t) = s(t) + iq(t)

is analytic. The complex trace, w, is called the analytic 
signal generated by the (real) trace, s. We may then 
calculate magnitude and phase of the analytic signal 
using the expressions

and 
0(t) = arctan [q(t)/s(t)],

respectively. 
R has been called the 'reflection strength' or 'reflec- 
tion energy' and 0 the 'instantaneous phase'. ~1 J 
We may also define an 'instantaneous frequency' 
equal to the derivative of 0 with respect to time, t. In 
practice, instantaneous frequency is often smoothed by 
averaging this quantity over some window weighted 
by reflection strength, for example. The result is called 
'averaged weighted frequency'. 
These attributes can be useful when used alone, or in 
conjunction with other attributes to make inferences 
concerning the lithological characteristics of the layers 
which bound a reflecting horizon. 
Reflection energy, R (also called the complex envel- 
ope), is not the usual envelope which we imagine 
associated with the real trace, s. It can be a useful

(e) 
if)

Fig. 5. Some common hydrocarbon traps. [J. H. Justice, Array processing in exploration seismology, Array 
Sional Processino. S. Haykin, ed., p. 28 (1985). Reprinted by permission of Prentice-Hall, Inc., Englewood 
Cliffs, NJ.]

discriminator between reflections which result from 
constructive interference of several smaller reflections 
rather than from a single large reflection/3) In partic- 
ular, a composite reflection may vary considerably 
along a line as the component reflections change, 
whereas a single reflector will tend to yield a constant 
R along the line. 
Instantaneous phase can be an extremely useful 
quantity in tracking reflection events since curves of 
constant phase should delineate a reflector very well 
across the section, this quantity being independent of 
reflection strength. As a result, weak but coherent 
events may be emphasized in this display. An instan- 
taneous phase display is used in Fig. 9 (shown 
superimposed with amplitude). This type of display can 
form a useful adjunct to facies analysis based on 
geometry and can be used in place of the zero-crossing

display mentioned earlier. We might point out that 
sudden and easily detected phase changes can occur 
with the onset of each new reflection event so that the 
phase display tends to resemble an image enhanced 
section. 
Frequency, either instantaneous or weighted can be 
a useful indicator of absorption where this is signifi- 
cant enough to be observed. The major example of this 
would be as a direct hydrocarbon indicator. Gas 
charged reservoirs are known to be strongly attenuat- 
ing to high frequencies in the seismic signal. These 
reservoirs often exhibit characteristic low frequency
